p:
As we access news from social media
1 , we are exposed to a daily dose of false or misleading news reports, hoaxes, conspiracy theories, click-bait headlines, junk science, and even satire
2 . We refer to such content collectively as “misinformation.” The financial incentives through advertising are well understood
3 , but political motives can be equally powerful
4, 5 . The massive spread of digital misinformation has been identified as a major global risk
6 and alleged to influence elections and threaten democracies
7 . While such claims are hard to prove
8 , real harm of disinformation has been demonstrated in health and finance
9, 10 .
